title: Snow Patrol’s Gary Lightbody fears he will have dementia as his father suffers with the condition
text:

Gary Lightbody believes he is destined for dementia after watching his father suffer from the disease.

The Snow Patrol musician, 43, has discussed how he has "always had memory problems" and that he is "trying to get ahead of it in his forties" following seeing his dad's memory decline following diagnosis in 2015.

Opening up on his fears, the Chasing Cars hitmaker shared that he sometimes "immediately forgets" song lyrics when he is on stage so is being proactive by doing brain training tasks daily.

Gary told The Sun: "My dad has dementia and I’ve always had memory problems. That’s been a lifetime problem.

“I’m sure that it will run to me and that’s why I’m trying to get on top of it in my forties, rather than leave it any later."

“Hopefully I’ve got a few years yet before that affects me. Memory is close to my heart and on my mind. I’ve been trying to do memory exercises."

In March last year, Gary told he was two-years sober following a secret battle with depression and alcoholism.

The lead singer told how his troubles started in his teenage years but spiralled out of control as he struggled to cope with his father's dementia diagnosis.

(Image: Getty)

Speaking to BBC Radio Two's Joe Whiley, Lightbody said he's reunited with his former bandmates and is preparing to release new music, which he says deals with 'the heavy stuff.'

"[The new album] comes from quite a lot of kind of heavy soul searching, like depression that I've suffered with from I was a kid, I never really spoke about that before, my father's dementia, he's had dementia for a few years now, my alcoholism and that I am sober now for two years, and am able to speak about it with clarity and with hope," said Gary.

Opening up about his depression which he said he's struggled with from he was a teenager, he said: "When it hits me it takes so much, and I'm sure that's the same with everyone and people are incapacitated, I mean friends of mine who I've spoken about it with have had similar experiences, like nothing make sense and there is no light and trying to write in that place is extremely difficult, you have to kind of get out of that place before you can write about it."

(Image: Getty Images Europe)

Bangor native Gary formed the band Shrug at Dundee University in 1994 with pals Mark McClelland and Michael Morrison.

They then changed their name to Snow Patrol and shot to fame with 2003 album Final Straw.

The group have some great accolades to their name such as their 2006 Eyes Open topping the charts and its hit single Chasing Cars became the most-played song on UK radio of the 21st Century.
description: The Snow Patrol star is concerned he, like his father Jack, will suffer from dementia as he ages
